job_title: Patient Food Service Representative in Gainesville, GA
pros: Your coworkers are great people. Loved the floor i was assigned to. The pay was good.
cons: Management is AWFUL! The job is very chaotic and it doesn't have to be that way. Their attendance policy is completely ridiculous. Even if you have a doctors excuse telling you that you can't work it is an unexcused absence and they will fire you if you miss 10 days in 12 months, no matter how good you are at your job. You lose all your vaction/sick day hours if you are terminated. The department is severely understaffed and they put way to much work on one person because of it. There is no hazard pay for working during the Covid pandemic. You are not appreciated for the extra work you do.

review_title: Good organization except for the IT Department
pros: Good benefits, decent salary, good relations with Providers and operational staff
cons: The IT department has a leadership void, in actions and in vision. You will hear the CIO say "it's about the relationships..". This is a nicer way of saying things work by the "old boy system..". All of the leadership in IT goes back to their days at CHOA and they look out for their interest only and unfortunately that has led to a reputation for incompetence among the folks in Operations, who will openly proclaim that they don't expect much from IT. People in management know how to be the boss but few know how to be leaders and inspire those who actually do the work. If you end up with a position in IT at NGHS, be prepared to be either micro-managed or ignored completely. Regardless, be prepared to give up any idea of independent though or autonomy. Do as you are told and be a good soldier and you will survive. But if you actually like to think for yourself then you will be miserable until you leave yourself or are asked to leave.

pros: Great people to work with

pros: The pay  was good for not having to do anything besides observe
cons:
*** You WILL have SOME coworkers give you ATTITUDE for not helping them lift a patient. PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE do not risk your job to avoid a bad time with a coworker. Kindly REMIND coworkers what you are NOT allowed to do because you WILL get in trouble IF A PATIENT IS HURT by you doing something, not in your duties.

*** PRAY, and I mean PRAY for day shift. It is difficult to just watch a patient at night and not be able to do ANYTHING. 
*** You are NOT allowed to feed a patient nor help the rest of the nursing staff. Only a PCT can. It's totally fine if you don't want to anyway but it is AWKWARD when the floor PCT's are busy and you have to perfectly good hands and the patient is looking at you like "Why can't you help me?". You do not want to get in trouble if WHILE feeding a patient they ASPIRATE.
*** You are also NOT allowed to help a patient walk to the bathroom if they are unsteady. A PCT must do this as well because if they FALL on your watch you are in trouble. 
*** Nursing staff is not always around/helpful. Let's just say not many people like sitters on their floor because they cannot really help with bed baths, walking to bathroom I.E  CNA/PCT duties.

pros: Organization really cares about its employees

job_title: PCT Patient Care Tech in Gainesville, GA

pros: Excellent Facilities and respectful colleagues
cons: Long hours, delayed bonus pay

review_title: Too quick of expansion, not enough leadership or vision, and WAY TOO MUCH turnover at all levels
pros: Good to get your foot in the door in healthcare.  They aren't overly rigid due to a lack of candidates, so you can get your foot in the door even if you have minimal experience.
cons: Leadership is abysmal and the turnover at the C suite level is alarming.  They have a genuine lack of direction, very unclear objectives, next to nothing as far as role definition.  There is no competition in the area, so the system can do what it wants and doctors and employees really have no say or way to change that.  The IT infrastructure is worse than the leadership.  Pay is significantly lower than you can find elsewhere.  The system claims they are 'rural' but they are only about 10 minutes from health companies that pay 20% more.

review_title: Nice place to work; once you're in, it is very hard to be let go.
job_title: "Employee" In the Operating Room in Gainesville, GA
pros:
Clean work environment and constantly given little appreciation gifts.
Short of killing someone, your job is almost definitely secure. Management does NOT have the backbone to fire you ESPECIALLY if you play the race/sex/disability card(s).
cons: You can have coworkers that are lazy, because they know they will not be fired. They know how to play the race/sex/disability card(s).

review_title: Watch your back and protect yourself
pros: Good learning experience. Pay scale is good.
cons: Management is worst. When time comes, no one will stand by you. Management is reactive rather than proactive. Simply because of lack of talent in the town and because some people click with some certain people, they get management position without any experience. Rude Directors and cunning directors who will use you and throw you off. Make sure to cover your back. Everyone will give you great lecture that we should help each other and share knowledge but you should be able to understand undertone which means if you have knowledge, I want to learn from you but if I have knowledge I am not going to teach.

pros: Great people to work with! The individual units really work as a good team. Met life-long friends there. Loved the actual job!
cons: No recognition for the going above and beyond. LOTS of favoritism shown. When the managers like you, they shun everyone else. It makes it easy for people to advance but harder for GOOD people to advance. It's almost like a high school clique in the cafeteria. Senior management is disconnected from everyone else. Too busy trying to expand but letting their employees fall to the wayside.

review_title: Overall great place with few exceptions
pros: I have worked here over 20 years in many different departments. Overall I have enjoyed working here. The people I have worked with and worked for have been amazing and care about the patients, co-workers and each other.
cons: If your not clinical upper management is not concerned about your pay or professional growth. They are only concerned about taking care of the nurses which is great but takes everyone to run a hospital. Communication between departments and upper management with employees needs work. Longevity in one organization doesn’t mean anything anymore and they don’t try to help you find other jobs throughout organization.

review_title: Culture shift not a good change
pros: lots of new building and improvements (although not at its nursing homes), good talented clinicians and doctors
cons: The organization will have you participating in surveys constantly and pressure for "good" responses because they are super focused on trying to win awards for everything under the sun.

job_title: PCT Unit Assistant in New Ross
pros: Lots of positions, locations, and opportunities to move up in the hospital. Great medical benefits, 401k, PDOs for full/part time employees, even an education reimbursement program. Great cafeteria which discounts for employees. The hospital has a great servant culture, striving for optimum patient satisfaction. Top Cardiology teams, and very friendly doctors.
cons: Some times departments are so short staffed, they will as you to take on more work. That's fine, but they do not compensate for the extra work done. I do my job, plus half an administrator's work and fill in for another position when said person is gone. When asked for a raise to compensate for all the extra work, I was denied.

pros: Great place to work. Staff is all very friendly and welcoming. The over all positive vibe throughout the hospital makes coming to work less stressful.
cons: Staffing floors based on the acuity of a horrible charting system leaves us short staffed, overworked, and unable to safely take care of patients. This has led to a problem with retention of nurses and nurse burnout. On top of that taking away our incentives for overtime shifts for the nurses that are actually willing to work overtime- is a slap in the face.

pros: I found this hospital system to be the most dishonest and corrupt one that I have ever worked for or even heard of. I would never consider working there or going there as a patient. They out right lied to me as working RN in their long term care facility and as a patient. A Physician there lied to me concerning my surgery and about my care which caused me my health. There was no Pros to being there.
cons: A surgeon lied to me about placing a screw on top of my vein to my leg during a back surgery. He said that was standard practice.  When I was hired to NGMS the Nursing Home Administratration lied to me about wanting  to improve the Nursing care that was given there. Instead they chose to continue having LPNs and Rns write Drs orders without notifying the Drs.

pros: The monetary compensation is competitive.  NGHS pays well, as good as any hospital in Atlanta.  Gainesville and the surrounding area is a great place to live.The hospital has attentive physicians. The hospital has dreams of being big among hospitals in georgia and says that strides are being made to remain competitive in technology and skill.
cons: Small town politics seems to be rampent in Georgia.  The era of good ole' boy has been handed off to good ole' girl.  A lot of defensiveness among managers when confronting clinical experience in employees.

review_title: Not what I was hoping for....
pros: The hourly wage was very good and above other hospitals for the professional. The manager had their favorite employees and if you were not on that list, you felt pretty worthless.  Your thoughts, suggestions, etc. were not considered at all.
cons: I can say that this was the worst hospital I have ever worked for. The management team that I worked under were not progressive with their management style; very punitive.  It doesn't take any talent to being that type of manager.

review_title: Excellent health system with growing pains
pros: good market growth, good quality care, organization interested in continually improving and updating process and quality of care
cons: growing pains...ie. loss of cohesiveness amongst all of the different campuses and offices outside the main hospital campus, organization needs to pick an approach or philosophy and stay with it longer than 2 years or so.   senior management needs to be more present with employees.  Directors need to be more aware of day to day operations and the work load on staff and supervisors

review_title: It's a good place to work
pros: Decent benefits. Most of  the supervisors  & doctors are good to work for.  They work good with you on your schedule.
cons: If you apply online for position you are pretty much appling for a position that someone in the system has already applied for.  You might get an interview but it takes several months for them to get back to you, if they have a position.

job_title: Low Man In the Totem Pole in Gainesville, GA
pros:
Good salaries and benefits.
Upper management seems to be trying to change the culture- not successfully, but trying.
cons:
Chronically understaffed departments..
Promotions not based on merit- it's who you know.
Mid- and low-level management woefully undertrained in HR and leadership skills. Management does not care. 
Management tends to pass the bucket- no one is responsible for making decisions

pros: Upper Management strives to follow mission and support all workers.
cons: Some management policies put into place don't seem well thought out on the user level and have to be revised after implementation.  I have seen how complacent employees and low morality in some locations cause frustration or consternation for others when ignored.  I have heard that anonymous complaints were well known by many who should not have known; thus, raising the questions of trust between employee and management.

pros: Braselton campus is new and new equipment. The pay is reasonable. Not the best. Some staff are nice and you make lifelong friends
cons: Worst benefits ever. Environment is very clicky. It's a circle of favorites of mgmt who survive and get promoted. It's an atmosphere of white superiority and sticking together to Demonize certain nurses who challenge their way of doing things. Complaints don't get resolved. They have incompetent charge nurses who they call PCFs who don't take patients. Some are good. Most not. They have a manager running too many units. Hires incompetent inexperienced nurses and they don't value seasoned nurses. Turnover is highest I've ever seen. Everyone variances petty stuff and they waste so much money here. Too many chiefs here and no Indians. 3-4 charge nurses working in day on one unit doing "office" but just sitting around talking bad about staff and manager who actually trusts these people and allows them to suck all the money out of nghs. Where is the ceo and why can't joint commission be the ones to oversee their operations?

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse (LPN) in Charlottesville, VA
pros: Stability, and pride in the work you do. Also, the employee benefits are great. You also work with highly experienced colleagues, and it is a great place to learn a very useful set of skills for your professional future.
cons: Management could be better, and the infrastructure could be modernized a bit. Also, the savings plan is very fair, but it could always be slightly improved which im sure would be very much appreciated.

pros: Good benefits, pleasant working environment. I enjoy my work, and like the fact that I am contributing to the health of my community, by working at a hospital.
cons: It can be difficult to find advancement opportunities if you are not a clinician. Management does not seem interested in actively helping current employees improve their skills, or help evaluate their current abilities as they could contribute further to the organization.

pros: Against traffic commute.  Modern updated facilities and state of the art equipment and applications.
cons: There is no standards for employee work.  some work from home, most can't, some come in late and leave early, while others are strictly watched and disciplined.  Some have little to no work or responsibilities, while other are over worked putting 50-60 hours a week.   The Epic project is grossly mis-managed and is set for an Epic failure.  How employees are being treated should be investigated by NGHS management.

pros: Good pay compared to similar jobs in same capacity.  Nice building to work in.  Great co-workers  in my dept. Work 3 1/2 days a week, off 3 1/2!
cons: Nurses and other health care professionals can be rude and  condescending to us support staff. The rules we are to abide by change depending on the nurses working, if their friends or family visit,  or their current mood.

pros: I love working here but need something I can do from home.. the only complaint is I feel under appreciated.. I’ve been with them for 15 years and have asked to be considered for more responsibility and higher position but this does not happen . I’m a very great dedicated employee so it’s frustrating . Overall a great company to work for.
cons: A better appreciation for long term employees and a better healthcare plan would always be a good idea. Also better options in our employee cafeteria.

review_title: NGHS a great place to work, but, has room for improvement.
job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse (LPN) in Gainesville, GA
pros: NGHS has excellent equipment, facilities, and wide range of patient care services/supplies always close at hand. Despite it's size their is a great sense of family. Changes are being made that hopefully will improve INADEQUATE staffing and retention issues. If you want extra work or a little overtime, the opportunity is there. Overall, NGHS is a great place to work! Benefits are adequate. Training is excellent. Staff typically work with smiles on their faces and a can do team spirit.
cons: The largest barrier to providing an optimum work environment and patient care is the institution of the electronic environment: Paragon. Inadequate staffing issues prevail due to reactive management style rather than proactive, a disconnect between administrative/patient care goals and staffing needs, and lack of using affordable resources such as PRN & Float Pool staff, the LPN, and the PCT . NGHS ignores the cost-effective care value of LPN's by not using them in roles commensurate with their education, thus, failing the RN and the patient in the Acute Care setting. Compensation is mediocre and recent reductions to pay scales, causing many in-place compensation rates to decline significantly, has lowered morale and caused loss of tenured knowledgeable staff RN's.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Braselton, GA
pros: Best reason to work here is the people at the hourly level. Compensation is very average. Scheduling is also a plus since you schedule yourself.
cons: NGHS is not going to go above and beyond for hourly employees compensation. They will do the bare minimum to keep you employed here. Senior leadership is a joke to deal with. They tell you what you want to hear but don't act.

review_title: poor pay, lots of warm bodies
pros: this is a great job in the OR if you need expirience to go to another job the docs are usually vey nice and will help if needed
cons: administration thinks that they can play with the big dogs with little dog expirience ,pay is not that great, spouses are not covered by insurance if offered at their job , training is not that great, benefits are horrible, if you are not friend or family with management your screwed

review_title: Was a great place 2 years ago...
job_title: Patient Care Technician in Braselton, GA
pros: Great place to work if you are a RN but I’m not one. I love working in the newer facility with the outside view of the pond, greenery, and the new waterfall to go outside and unwind on the warmer days. The flexibility to make your own schedule is great (although I’m not sure if that is just something that comes with any PCT job in a hospital). Many of the upper level doctors/nurses have great personalities.
cons: The downside of this position really come from upstairs. They have decided to fire all of the secretaries in a mass exodus to save money and dumped all of their responsibilities chart making, breaking, discharges, phone calls, etc on the PCT with NO increase in pay. You consistently have 12 patients which wouldn’t be so bad if you didn’t have to chart everything that you do for each individual patient, while being expected to document intake (breakfast, lunch, dinner), output (stool/ urine), 3 sets of vital signs, on top of trying to bathe/ change linen, all while being bombarded by calls. It doesn’t matter how busy you are because you don’t get any help from the nursing staff. I’ve had nurses walk out of a room, go past the nourishment room, to find me and say the patient needs water. Nursing will go into a patient room to do their work up of a patient and upon leaving, push the tech button on the phone to help THEIR patient to the bathroom. The lack of teamwork and value of lower employee satisfaction really show when you get on the inside. All three of the PCT’s that I know have left are all much happier with the culture, workload, and better pay of their new job. Knowing what I know now, I would only apply here if you are really desperate for contact hours or trying to get your foot in the door. And I mean really desperate.

pros: Vastly growing, core values taken very seriously.  Good benefits.
cons: The NGPG (the physicians side of the organization) is separately operated from the medical center.  Do not expect to work for the medical center or that it is even managed by the human resources or the hospital.  Does not run in sync with the hospital standards or core values.

review_title: All those awards must mean something
pros: If you sit in a town hall or division meeting you will hear wonderful things. People are trying to do good things.
cons: Every month there is a new buzzword and accompanying change in philosophy: A3, Lean, Quest.... There is no follow through after the initial burst of energy for the implementation.

pros: Salary is competitive and generally good.
cons:
Long working hours (14 hours shifts can be needed).
No continuing education.
Must work as a temp or help desk before transitioning into other roles.
Cannot advice your careers unless you become EPIC certified. (They won't pay)

pros: Location - it is closer to my house than any other hospital.
cons: Patient safety is not a priority!!! Neither is employee satisfaction. Management lie frequently about upcoming changes. I do not trust what anyone says because tomorrow it will be a completely different story. No sense of trust or job security.

job_title: Patient Access Representative II in Oakwood, GA
pros: Very professional atmosphere. Generally really nice people that you work with, training is good and thorough.
cons: I will have a Masters degree in healthcare management and there is not a lot of options to be able to advance. Too many people want the same job, usually older and have been there longer, so younger people coming out of school with higher degrees do not have as good of a chance getting a job right away. Its also about who you know around here

job_title: PCT Patient Care Tech in Gainesville, GA
pros: Guaranteed full time hours for 12 weeks during the summer. If you continue working through the school year PRN, you are seen as strongly preferred for nurse residency offers when you graduate
cons: This position is in med/surg resource pool, so it's not a great fit for someone who isn't interested in that area of nursing. You're also not allowed to do anything under the supervision of an RN like you would in clinicals, only allowed to function as a PCT.

review_title: Please offer competitive pay to loyal employees
pros: Staff is friendly and scheduling is flexible.
cons: No room for growth or better pay.  Everyone knows that you have to leave  the company and return in order to get competitive pay.  There are new nurses having >3-4 yrs exp with no critical care or ICU/ER experience  hired that make $3-$4 an hour more than employees working 5-10 yrs here that have critical care experience.

pros: Great people to work with and develop business relations with and very busy work environment that offers high paced work and detail experience.
cons: Poor work hours with very little flexibility and multiple situations where staff is extremely understaffed with little support, encouragement, and feelings of being stressed.

pros: Great benefits.  The opportunity to advance is great too.
cons: The hospital itself is great. Other units are great.... other jobs are great... being a PCT sucks... being a PCT  on S3E  Sucks even worst. Short staffed on the pct level all the time. PCT's get 11 patients, and the nurses get 4. However, expect you to do a lot of things without helping. The pay for a PCT is absolute crap.  You have to wait 1 year to transfer.

review_title: Hospital is a good place. Management is very bad
pros: Pto Benefits close at 6:30 The latest you have to be there is 730 earliest so you have to be there is 530
cons: Supervisors and managers do not know how to manage a team or how to communicate. Retail manager plays favorites with schedule. Sweeps everything under the rug until it’s too late

pros: Great place to gain experience.  Wonderful coworkers. You can easily transfer within the company to other positions.  First company that I have been with that will work with your availability schedule.  If you are a student they will make a schedule around your available days instead of you trying to fit in class while working.
cons: Compensation is low compared to other phlebotomist positions.  There is night time differential of $1.50/hr

pros: New department, new equipment great list of surgeons. Very good care for the patient well respected in the community as a great hospital for care.
cons: Employee are not well supported. Losing a lot of long term employees. High staff turnover which creates a situation where the department can't handle the work day volume.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Gainesville, GA
pros: Friendly staff and management. Lots of room for growth. Great vision for the future of Healthcare. Great benefits and differential pay with competitive salaries.
cons: Hospital really needs to update the South tower to align it with all the new areasite that have been built around it.

pros: People who work here are generally happy and friendly. Generous shift differentials have made a big difference on my pay. Even PRN staff get 401k. My manager and director are very accessible and love to get feedback on the department.
cons: Current EMR is McKesson Paragon, which is not the most intuitive or efficient. However, this will be greatly improved by moving to Epic in the next couple years.

pros: Yearly pay raise (approx. $0.20/hr) if you completed continuing education and did not have any disciplinary actions. The company "self-insures" meaning that when you go to the doctor and they bill your insurance company for $400, and the insurance company pays $320, NGHS is writing that check for the negotiated rate. They have incentives for people who do not smoke to have a reduced premium, if you submit to a drug test and wellness check-up.  Pay is much better compared to other rural hospitals, but is obviously much lower than what you may be offered at an Atlanta hospital.  Since people are quitting left and right and there is a mass exitus, there are plenty of job openings.
cons:
Unfortunately this hospital has succumbed to believing that hospitals are ran like 5-star hotels, and have created a rating system that is constantly abused by patrons, or patients as they were once called. Nursing staff are measured not on the level of care given, but if their pain was alleviated, if the nurse responded to a call button within 20 seconds, if they felt they had to wait too long, if the nurse retrieved food for them if they were hungry, and many other factors that are not only out of the control of nursing staff, but also require them to jeopardize the quality of care given. When a nurse receives bad reviews, a mass email is sent out criticizing nurses and their "lack of compassion". The nurse then has a 1 on 1 meeting with their PCC and is berated instead of being asked to explain the situation. In fact, they are usually told how they could be fired. 

The year is 2014 and the ED is paper charting - why you may ask? The hospital was talked into a new charting system called Paragon. The launch was such a failure, despite warnings from staff early on the in the training process, that the ED has decided that paper charting is more efficient than dealing with this failure; other departments have not been as lucky. Highlighting just a few features of Paragon: It looks like Windows Paint on an old Windows 2000 system with less than intuitive icons, there is not a free-text area - let me say that again, you cannot simply write anything - a user must select predefined terms and ailments, these pre-defined terms and conditions were written by programmers who have never once stepped foot in a hospital; especially an ER. Also, Nurses must scan medications, patient’s arm bands, which may work on a floor, but when John Doe is bleeding out there is no time to be scanning medications. To validate how serious of a failure Paragon is, the Chief Information Officer was fired/resigned over the incident, and the new hospital in Braselton will not be using Paragon. However, you can expect to continue to see the system in use at the Gainesville location. 

The first two paragraphs highlight the wonderful culture there at NGHS, which has in turn resulted in a "Mass Exitus". In fact the primary reason that the ED chose to go to paper charting vs Paragon, was because more than half of the ED staff turned in notices they were quitting, many of these nurses simply to go work in retail or another non-medical field rather than stay and lose their license from Paragon. However, this decision to drop Paragon came much too late, so the ED was forced to eat the cost of Travel nurses for the next 6 months. Despite many offering to stay thru the holidays, the hospital let the travel nurses go before the new hires were even on their first day without a shadow, which leads us to our next problem.

Such a protest by the nurses must obviously be punished, so the ED issued a decree in early October stating that if you are absent or tardy more than twice (2 times) in 6 months, you will be fired. Let me elaborate, this is ANY absence or ANY tardy, not just unexcused. So going into November, if you get pneumonia or the flu (from those pesky sick patients in the ER), don't worry about coming to work when you feel better, you'll be fired. As if that was ludicrous enough, this decree was not just for the 6 months going forward, they looked at the 6 months prior to the rule and if you had more than 2 absences or tardy days (again even sick days, leave early for emergencies, or forgot to clock in, or flat tires) you were warned not to miss or be late another day for 6 months. How serious are they, I know of a few people who have already been fired. Two of these ladies because of the "backdating" I just mentioned. So here we are with 100's of PDO hours in case we get sick that we cannot use. 

So just to recap, the thoughts going through a Nurse's mind at any given time is: I have 4 patients, 2 are stable and need to be discharged, we can't make them wait too long to be discharged because they will give me a bad review. I have had them all of 1 hour, but they spent 3 hours in the waiting room because they only have a cough, I hope I don't catch that because I can't be out sick or I will get fired, oh and they will give me a bad review for their wait time. Also I need to be 1 on 1 for the next 30 minutes with this patient while I start Levo in case they start to bleed, but then there's that other patient they just bedded back here I have not even seen yet. If she has to wait too long to see me they may give me a bad review. The printer is out of ink again, need to get that replaced because we are still paper charting, so I can't chart the procedures I am about to do or print discharge papers. I guess I will introduce myself and get vitals on this new patient; hopefully the Levo patient's BP doesn't spiral down.

I could go on, but these are the most asinine of the offenses which I think do a good job of conveying the culture you are in for if you come to the NGHS Emergency Department. However, staffing is a problem everywhere in the hospital thanks to Paragon and the Hotel satisfaction surveys. Also, note I only highlighted the failures of Paragon specific to ED, but the system itself is constantly down and just as buggy as the old system.

job_title: Mental Health Technician in Gainesville, GA
pros: Most shifts are 7 on - 7 off, which allows for picking up extra shifts (one can even go outside Laurelwood and cross train anywhere in Northeast Georgia Medical Center) or for taking week log vacations.
cons: No cons that one won't find anywhere (e.g. employees thinking they know what is best and thus not allowing themselves to learn and adjust, gossip, some employees are burnt out, etc).

pros: Employees are trusted to do their jobs without "micromanagement",  good work/life balance, coaching rather than punitive atmosphere.
cons: Raises and bonuses were decreased last year due to opening of new hospital.

pros: Great People, good benefits, stable company
cons: Hiring process is horrible.  Even if you are qualifed for the job, you have to know someone.

job_title: MHT, Unit Secretary in Gainesville, GA
pros: Great team of nursing, therapists, MHT, doctors.
cons: Sometimes things get physical with the patients and that’s kind of a downside for staff, due to having to  medicate  patients will put them in restraints.

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Braselton, GA
pros: Progressive company, sustainable use of energy, land around hospital.  Upper management (within pharmacy) attentive to needs and concerns of employees.  Able to use larger facilities resources when needed.  Makes a serious effort to make everyone within department feel included as a team.
cons: Some discipline actions are too lenient and insubordination isn't disciplined.  Not enough PRN staff coverage.

pros: Location, nice people in the accounting department
cons: Little to no training; no written procedures for this particular position; the position was truly not necessary in the department; the insurance was expensive for the family group

job_title: Medical and Clinical Laboratory Technologist in Gainesville, GA
pros: The Management in the laboratory is great. The people are great. Flexible Scheduling. Great environment.
cons: Pay can be better. NGHS gets a huge workload and for this reason I believe we are underpaid in the lab. When compared to other organizations, the workload is 6x as much and pay is still under what other organizations offer.

pros:
There are good co workers.
Location is ideal
Plenty of position openings 
Growing rapidly
I really can’t think of anything else.
cons:
Low pay especially for the workload
Favoritism is a big issue
Very hard to transfer or be promoted 
Workload is not distributed evenly. Some people have too much work while others twiddle their thumbs.

pros: Great work environment. Had good interactions with staff & leadership. Pay and benefits were the best I've had anywhere.
cons: Not many. Nothing unusual from other work environments. Leadership does need to prioritize projects and learn to say 'no' to clinical staff demands as this stretches resources thinner and thinner.

pros: benefits, shift diff, coworkers, normally have a great shift with great people to work with
cons: unit management could be better handled by upper management sometimes I wonder if they are being made to do their job at all

pros: great knowledgable staff, team work oriented environment, positive culture

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Gainesville, GA

pros: Great team work and the management that I have worked with is caring and concerned about the employees.

review_title: I had a great time  working for them
job_title: Patient Care Tech in Gainesville, GA

pros: Great Benefits, Community Atmosphere, and employee events.
